summary: about aziraphale being fat and old and also the hottest thing crowley has ever known
title: about aziraphale being fat and old and also the hottest thing crowley has ever known
body:
i keep starting and stopping this post in my head, so i’m just gonna write it down. now, i’ll be very clear from the get-go: there is certainly a value in being attracted to a lover’s personality, to the light that shines in their eyes, the soft curve of their lip, the sound of their laugh, the way they hold their hands, the way they say “i love you”, their fastidious and funny little ways, their stupid jokes, etc, etc.

this post is not about that. there’s often a tone re: aziraphale’s weight that kind comes across as, “oh, but crowley is still attracted to him bc of his personality,” like YEAH, that, but also, his body. you don’t need to go, ”oh it’s all about his personality”, like, his body is GREAT 

so, let’s define the aziraphale that i’m talking about here. let’s say, from an average person’s POV, he looks to be in his mid-fifties, which is one thing on its own. like, people can have… wrinkles. these can be sexy. laughter lines, crow’s feet, everpresent dimples. they’re marks of wear and tear, sure, but that’s where the expression is: a smile laid that valley around his mouth; his laughter created those lines at his eyes; his cute little concentrated frown made that furrow in his brow. 

 and he is, shall we say… well-proportioned? he’s fat. that’s what we mean: that’s what we’ll say. he’s fat. this does not, in fact, mean that he’s super skinny, with skinny legs and skinny arms, and like, a slightly rounded belly, no.

he’s meaty. if you start from his shoulders, he will be broader. you won’t see his collarbone from across the room, sharp enough to cut glass. the flesh settles thick on the bones, gives it all the cushioning it needs. his breast is not all that flat: it’s warm and fat and pillowy on each side, and then he has the round curve to his belly. but the thing is, like… when you’re chubby and you have that rounded form, it isn’t just a little curve in the front: it’s heavy on the sides, too, and cushions the hips.

because of the way our bodies gather fat, you’re not gonna have two straight lines for legs: aziraphale’s thighs will be super generously proportioned, but his calves will be less so, and most of the fat will land around his seat - his arse (it’s absolutely a fat arse, o yes), and the tops of his thighs. his arms will have the same kind of thing - they’ll be thicker in the upper arm than in the forearm. there’ll also probably be more wobble to the thighs and the upper arms than to the calves and to the forearms.

and his hands!!! plump hands! so soft! 

there’s a tendency, when it comes to bodies that are fat, to avert the gaze. we look away, because there’s this overwhelming narrative of thin bodies being the only good bodies, and we’re subsequently quite uncomfortable with bodies that aren’t slender or like, muscled. bc there’s that conditioning to look away from fat bodies, to see them as ugly or inherently unhealthy, when neither is true whatsoever, we also tend to desexualise fat bodies, and i defo think that that’s maybe part of the reason there’s that big thing of like, focusing on aziraphale as thinner and conventionally handsome. 

crowley does not have that tendency. he does not look at aziraphale’s body and think that he should be thinner. crowley’s lifetime has spanned a multitude of epochs, and the connotations of aziraphale’s body might have been calculated to deter any mortals that might want to come onto him, but they sure as fuck can’t deter crowley. 

listen. 

aziraphale’s body is hefty. it’s meaty. 

it’s a body that says, in a language far older than magazines and television and advertisements for not-meals, “yes, i eat and drink and i lead a life of indolence, bc i can.” his hands are soft and plump and pretty: aziraphale doesn’t work outside, doesn’t labour and doesn’t toil. he does soft, inside work, and he’s genteel. his body is fat and pillowy: crowley can reach out and grab fistfuls of his lovehandles, feel the flesh yield beneath his touch; he can playfully smack aziraphale’s thigh, watch it jiggle and quake under the light blow; he can feel aziraphale’s weight on him, pinning him down no matter how strong he really is. when he smiles, there are dimples: his cheeks are round and rosy, his lips are plump. 

when crowley lies on him, he radiates warmth, and he’s never cold: he’s soft and comfortable, and when he hugs crowley, he surrounds him. 

like, if you jump back about 500, 1000 years, 1500 years, AND FURTHER, aziraphale is a fucking catch. he’s fat - means he’s rich, means he doesn’t work outside too much! yes, he’s got a few years on him, but that just means he won’t run off and fuck around elsewhere! he’s got soft hands, a warm body, a warmer bed, no doubt, and like, listen, he’s got all his own teeth and everything!

aziraphale can be fat and old and sexy!

(and he is! crowley will say so!)

tags: idk if u have gleaned this
but i'm emo about greenhouses and i Love Them
summary: let crowley have a greenhouse. let him grow plants underneath the glass panes, the sun shining down on luscious, verdant leaves,...
body:
let crowley have a greenhouse.

let him grow plants underneath the glass panes, the sun shining down on luscious, verdant leaves, the scent of the air like ozone: let him remember what eden was, surrounded on every side by viridian splendour, the scent of heat and air and mulch and blossom thick on his tongue. let him stand, at times, in the middle of it all, leaning against his potting table, feeling naught more than the warmth of a sun he once knew millennia ago, the first time it kissed black scales and gave him a scant sliver of the warmth he knew with the Host

let him have his greenhouse.

let him love in it, and laugh in it: let him whisper dark threats to tomatoes and cucumbers, let him murmur evil words to the leaves of pepper plants, let him leave burning words on the skin of every chilli, that it grows riper and heavier with every day that passes.

let him stand in his greenhouse when the rain is falling, so that he can close his eyes and hear the thunder of every drop upon the glass panes, and feel, for just a moment, as if the world is ending.

and let aziraphale come up behind him, press a kiss to his shoulder, and say, “come inside, dear. it’s getting late.”

let him leave his eden behind him, every night, and follow the angel where he leads.

blog.name: they-handed-me-the-moon
blog.title: They Handed Me The Moon
blog.description: Paige, 23, she/her, queer. This blog is for whatever catches my interest, which for now is primarily Good Omens

tags: that's longer then intended but i don't have time to edit now
and its not worth going back to later
summary: So while we’re all on about the Eden scene, the thing about the "funny if we both got it wrong” line is that it could have been...
body:
So while we’re all on about the Eden scene, the thing about the “funny if we both got it wrong” line is that it could have been played a number of ways. It could be a passing joke, an anxious observation, a thoughtless comment recanted the next moment, a deliberate attempt to mess with Aziraphale.

But it also has the potential to be weighted with meaning, to be a revolutionary statement about who they are and what they are capable of, and an invitation to be delighted by the freedom instead of threatened by it. If pointedly and earnestly meant, it is a statement that reaches across the divide, that says, “I think perhaps we are not so different. Could you accept that?”

Then that Eden clip dropped and Crowley says the line with That smile and welp! Guess we’re going for the ‘weighted with meaning’ route, then! And yes Aziraphale pulls back, ostensibly refuses the invitation, but first he laughed. Because he’s not ready to face the implications of genuine freedom, not yet, not for 6000 years, but on a some level he not only already believes it but feels the joy of it. That and also Pretty Demon Smiled Nice and frankly he’s a bit flustered.

And so it goes. Aziraphale keeps saying the correct things, keeps telling himself he believes them. “You’re a demon, I’m an angel,” he says, “we do this, we can’t do that.” But his laughter is the true predictor of his actions. “Come in and have a drink just as you are, my demon friend. Tell me your anxieties and I’ll tell you mine. Let me help you with your work, we can lighten one another’s burdens. For we are the same, you and I. I will not say it, not even in private, but I will live by it.”

That and also Pretty Demon Smiled Nice and frankly he’s a bit flustered.

And so it goes. Aziraphale keeps saying the correct things, keeps telling himself he believes them. “You’re a demon, I’m an angel,” he says, “we do this, we can’t do that.” But his laughter is the true predictor of his actions. “Come in and have a drink just as you are, my demon friend. Tell me your anxieties and I’ll tell you mine. Let me help you with your work, we can lighten one another’s burdens. For we are the same, you and I. I will not say it, not even in private, but I will live by it.”
trail.content:
So while we’re all on about the Eden scene, the thing about the “funny if we both got it wrong” line is that it could have been played a number of ways. It could be a passing joke, an anxious observation, a thoughtless comment recanted the next moment, a deliberate attempt to mess with Aziraphale.

But it also has the potential to be weighted with meaning, to be a revolutionary statement about who they are and what they are capable of, and an invitation to be delighted by the freedom instead of threatened by it. If pointedly and earnestly meant, it is a statement that reaches across the divide, that says, “I think perhaps we are not so different. Could you accept that?”

Then that Eden clip dropped and Crowley says the line with That smile and welp! Guess we’re going for the ‘weighted with meaning’ route, then! And yes Aziraphale pulls back, ostensibly refuses the invitation, but first he laughed. Because he’s not ready to face the implications of genuine freedom, not yet, not for 6000 years, but on a some level he not only already believes it but feels the joy of it. That and also Pretty Demon Smiled Nice and frankly he’s a bit flustered.

And so it goes. Aziraphale keeps saying the correct things, keeps telling himself he believes them. “You’re a demon, I’m an angel,” he says, “we do this, we can’t do that.” But his laughter is the true predictor of his actions. “Come in and have a drink just as you are, my demon friend. Tell me your anxieties and I’ll tell you mine. Let me help you with your work, we can lighten one another’s burdens. For we are the same, you and I. I will not say it, not even in private, but I will live by it.”

summary: Do you guys think that sometimes when Aziraphale is getting annoyed while reading a book the story in it changes by itself?...
body: Do you guys think that sometimes when Aziraphale is getting annoyed while reading a book the story in it changes by itself? Like, say he’s reading a romance and he’s starting to get frustrated with all the pining, the “getting together at the last possible second” story turns, to its own surprise, into about 50k of fluff without Aziraphale realizing that’s his influence? Or does Crowley do it for him when he sees the angel frowning and Aziraphale to this day hasn’t noticed?

summary: THE J STANDS FOR JANELLE MONAE
title: THE J STANDS FOR JANELLE MONAE
body:
I must write a fic based loosely on the premise of Make Me Feel immediately

And by immediately I mean in about three months once I’m not frantically packing for my holiday, cramming a coursework deadline, trying to do continued professional development balls, working a nine day week until my holiday and then cramming for an exam I didn’t even realise I was actually having but I will be thinking about this concept every spare moment until then

title: Dun.
body:
My Ask | My Ko-Fi | On Ao3 | Requests always welcome!

He had been waiting, patiently. Or— He hadn’t, exactly. Neither waiting nor patience were especial watchwords for Anthony J. Crowley, and so what he’d really been doing was pacing around his flat waiting for words from on high – or, that is to say, on low. He hadn’t had words from on high for quite some time.

It’s been a few days.

All has, theoretically, gone back to normal.

All, except…

He flicked on the television, which had not been the most expensive in the shop, but had been the one with the most complicated remote, and that had rather appealed. He liked it when technology seemed very complicated to operate, and he ordinarily enjoyed the meditative nature of flicking through thirty buttons to do something as simple as turn the volume down a fraction.

Static played from the television.

“Hello?” he asked, cautiously, in the voice of one torn between hoping for one result or the other

No answer.

“Listen,” he said, “I’ve not had any orders, or any check-ins since… since it all went down, you know.”

No answer. The static buzzed, and Crowley began cycling through buttons. S4C, the Welsh-language television channel, flickered onto the screen, and he finally managed to turn the volume up slightly. He waited with bated breath for the melodic, easy sounds of Welsh to morph into the buzzing tones of one of his superiors.

It didn’t happen.

He flicked the television off, with only six wrong tries before he got the right button.

He’d been to the graveyard. Every other Tuesday was the meeting time, usually, and yet this Tuesday… No one. Nobody.

He moved toward the phone, but before he could reach for it, it rang, and he picked up the receiver, holding it to his ear.

“Angel,” Crowley said, “has nobody talked to you either?”

“Not a word,” Aziraphale said anxiously. He didn’t at all seem perturbed by the fact that Crowley knew who was calling. Perhaps he assumed that Crowley had some sort of technology to identify who was calling him[1]. “You don’t think…?”

“Well, he said put everything back to normal,” Crowley said.

“More or less,” Aziraphale muttered, without faith. “Have you, er, tried… Tried any official mode of contact, yet?”

“No,” Crowley said. “Just talked to the television. Why?”

“Well, I— You know. I… I dialled the direct line, as it were.”

“And?”

“Well, my dear, I might as well have called a friend from a century ago. There’s not just no answer. There’s no… There’s no tone. Er— You know what I mean?”

“Yeah,” Crowley said woodenly.

Aziraphale’s voice was terse and stiff and quiet, and Crowley drummed his fingers against the side of his television unit, feeling the uncomfortable, crawling tension in his chest as the angel went on. “But I— You know, I’m not… I hardly think we’ve been demoted, as it were. I remain in possession of my graces, and indeed, my Graces[2].”

“Very good, angel,” Crowley muttered, without enthusiasm. “Yeah, I haven’t noticed anything, but…”

“You don’t suppose they’ve…?”

“They can’t, can they?”

“I don’t see why not.”

“But that would stop us being…”

“I’m not so sure it would.”

“How’d you mean?”

There was a long, complicated pause on the other end of the line, and Crowley fancied he could see Aziraphale’s lips moving as he rehearsed what it was he wanted to say, tasting the words before he loaned them voice. Finally, he answered, “If he wants us to be as we are – that is to say, an angel and a demon – we are, we will be, an angel and a demon. But he… Well. I think the boy rather a similar flaw to mine, in that, ahem, he can’t really resist fixing something, if it might be fixed. And I was… I was thinking, dear boy, were I in such a position, what I might have done is just taken us off the books.”

Crowley understood. He wasn’t sure he liked that understanding, however, and so he repeated, “Taken us off the…?”

“Create a blindspot, as it were,” Aziraphale continued, without hearing him. “We are what we are. They are as they are. And never the twain shall meet.”

Crowley considered this for a long moment. The idea was unspeakable. To be as they were, but without their respective connections to Heaven and Hell, to be… Well. To be—

Unspeakable was right.

“Would you like to go for a drink?” Aziraphale asked, somewhat desperately.

“Oh, yes,” Crowley replied. “I’ll pick you up.”

–

They didn’t actually bother to go anywhere.

They sat down in the park, on the green, on a picnic blanket. It was a warm day, clinging onto the dregs of summer, and while they split a bottle of wine between them, none of the passing policemen on their beat much liked the idea of coming to break up their date. One of them was in a suit, and the other was in a thick wool jumper – suffice to stay, taking their Lafitte off them doesn’t seem like much cop when there were much more interesting bystanders to harass around London.

“What do we do?” Aziraphale asked.

“Dunno,” Crowley said. He took a sip of his wine, staring out over the duck pond. “Always thought about it. But I never really… I never really got as far as this point. I just thought, oh, wouldn’t it be nice…? And then thought about something else. Did you?”

“No,” Aziraphale said.

A beat passed. It spanned the silences of centuries.

“Yes,” he amended, guiltily, staring down at his knees, which were clad in sensible tan trousers. “But it was never going to happen. I— What is one to do?”

“Same stuff as always, I suppose,” Crowley said. “Just without reporting it to the men upstairs. Er, in your case, of course.”

“That’s not really cricket, is it?” Aziraphale asked.

Crowley, who did not believe the term “that’s not cricket” had been used by anyone else for at least a hundred years, said, “No.”

“I mean,” Aziraphale went on, “what would the point be? If we did it without reporting on it?”

“Human decency, I suppose,” Crowley said softly. Saying it didn’t avert the deep and crushing existential terror that was threatening to thunder down around his eyes, but it did meet a small bloom of satisfaction unfurl its flowers in his breast. He could be… He could be A.J. Crowley. He could just be… Anthony Crowley. No odd wishes, no giving up his powers, or his immortality. Just— Just being, and not having to report back downstairs.

His head spun.

“If it isn’t recorded, it hardly exists,” Aziraphale said, not really hearing Crowley. He was several leagues inside his own head, and he found the weather very unpleasant indeed. “Ergo, there’s no point doing it. And I’m… That is to say, one does rather need a point, to exist.”

“Why?” Crowley asked. “They don’t.” This was said with a vague gesture at the city around them. It was somewhat devoid of its usual, natural scorn. Then, he added, in a quietly hopeful tone, “And there’s the Arrangement[3].”

“But there’s no point to it,” Aziraphale snapped, “if there aren’t sides that we’re on. If we’re just— If we’re just you and me, dear boy, with the ties to our respective commands cut away, then the Arrangement becomes just that: you and me.”

“Yeah,” Crowley agreed, feeling himself grin. “Yeah, it does, doesn’t it?”

There was a long silence, and Crowley took a long sip of his drink, before glancing to his left, to see what had rendered Aziraphale silent. He followed Aziraphale’s downturned gaze, and his eyes alighted, through the dark lenses of his sunglasses, on his own hand. It was on top of Aziraphale’s, his fingers curled in to loosely clasp at it. The angel’s hand, Crowley noted, was quite warm, and his touch didn’t make Crowley’s body any more inclined to burst into flames, or to smoke, or do anything along those lines, than it usually was.

“Ah,” Aziraphale said. “Are you… Are you sure, my dear?”

“Nope,” Crowley said, with a grin. “I’m not sure of anything.” He squeezed. After another moment’s pause, Aziraphale’s hand shifted in his own, their fingers interlinking, and he heard Aziraphale exhale breathily. “D’you want to go to dinner?”

“Sushi?” Aziraphale asked, hopefully. He had scooted slightly closer, so that their shoulders were touching. If Crowley was a human, his cheeks would have flushed. He wasn’t one, but… What the Hell? He blushed anyway.

“Why not? Let’s… Let’s order just starters. Eat from the same plates.”

“We usually eat from the same plates,” Aziraphale said. By this, he meant, “I usually eat from your plate,” as Crowley did not have the same appetite Aziraphale did, and often left his food unfinished.

“Yes,” Crowley agreed. “Yes. But— But let’s make a spectacle of it.”

“We don’t know,” Aziraphale began.

“Yes, we do,” Crowley decided, and this was how he showed he’d decided: he leaned closer, so that his head rested on Aziraphale’s shoulder, still holding his hand. He could feel the heat of his flush burning his cheeks, and he could feel his body’s heart pumping a good deal more vigorously than usual. It was rather nice. “Yes,” he decided a second time, for good measure. “We do.”

“Oh,” Aziraphale said, breathlessly. “Yes, I… I suppose we do.”

For a long, long few minutes, they sat there, drinking their wine. Crowley leaned his head against Aziraphale’s shoulder, and Aziraphale put his cheek in toward the top of it, enjoying the spiced scent of the product Crowley wore to soften his hair.  The sun began to set over Soho.

“Crowley?” Aziraphale asked.

“Hm?”

“Let’s split a dessert.” It was said with such reckless enthusiasm that Crowley heard himself laugh. Later on, Aziraphale would eat the whole thing, bar for a mouthful, because Crowley wasn’t actually one for dessert, but the point would be the look of the thing, the spectacle, and they would order it together.

“Alright,” he agreed, readily. He raised his wine glass. “To our godson, then. He did very well without our influence, didn’t he?”

“Yes,” Aziraphale said, raising his own glass, and letting it clink against Crowley’s. “We should… We should visit him.”

“Would be nice to do,” Crowley mused. “What with us being— Being retired, and all.”

“Yes,” Aziraphale agreed. They drained their glasses. “Retired!”

“We could buy a cottage in Tadfield, and go there on weekends,” Crowley said impulsively. “Dunroamin.”

“Dunmiracling.”

“Dundemoning.”

“Dunangeling.”

“Dun.”

“Dun!”

They sat together in the silence, and as one, they fell back on the grass, staring up at the reddening skies, and feeling the warmth of each other’s palms, pressed tight together. In the stars, Crowley could divine no purpose at all.

It was unspeakable.

It was wonderful.

[1] In fact, Crowley did, but he hadn’t looked at it. He hadn’t needed to.

[2] One might mistakenly believe that one cannot capitalize words in spoken conversation, but Aziraphale rather had the knack.

[3] Crowley, too, was able to capitalise words with his voice alone, although he ordinarily needed to have heard Aziraphale performing the practice first. Luckily, he usually had.

He had been waiting, patiently. Or— He hadn’t, exactly. Neither waiting nor patience were especial watchwords for Anthony J. Crowley, and so what he’d really been doing was pacing around his flat waiting for words from on high – or, that is to say, on low. He hadn’t had words from on high for quite some time.

It’s been a few days.

All has, theoretically, gone back to normal.

All, except…

He flicked on the television, which had not been the most expensive in the shop, but had been the one with the most complicated remote, and that had rather appealed. He liked it when technology seemed very complicated to operate, and he ordinarily enjoyed the meditative nature of flicking through thirty buttons to do something as simple as turn the volume down a fraction.

Static played from the television.

“Hello?” he asked, cautiously, in the voice of one torn between hoping for one result or the other

No answer.

“Listen,” he said, “I’ve not had any orders, or any check-ins since… since it all went down, you know.”

[[MORE]]

No answer. The static buzzed, and Crowley began cycling through buttons. S4C, the Welsh-language television channel, flickered onto the screen, and he finally managed to turn the volume up slightly. He waited with bated breath for the melodic, easy sounds of Welsh to morph into the buzzing tones of one of his superiors.

It didn’t happen.

He flicked the television off, with only six wrong tries before he got the right button.

He’d been to the graveyard. Every other Tuesday was the meeting time, usually, and yet this Tuesday… No one. Nobody.

He moved toward the phone, but before he could reach for it, it rang, and he picked up the receiver, holding it to his ear.

“Angel,” Crowley said, “has nobody talked to you either?”

“Not a word,” Aziraphale said anxiously. He didn’t at all seem perturbed by the fact that Crowley knew who was calling. Perhaps he assumed that Crowley had some sort of technology to identify who was calling him[1]. “You don’t think…?”

“Well, he said put everything back to normal,” Crowley said.

“More or less,” Aziraphale muttered, without faith. “Have you, er, tried… Tried any official mode of contact, yet?”

“No,” Crowley said. “Just talked to the television. Why?”

“Well, I— You know. I… I dialled the direct line, as it were.”

“And?”

“Well, my dear, I might as well have called a friend from a century ago. There’s not just no answer. There’s no… There’s no tone. Er— You know what I mean?”

“Yeah,” Crowley said woodenly.

Aziraphale’s voice was terse and stiff and quiet, and Crowley drummed his fingers against the side of his television unit, feeling the uncomfortable, crawling tension in his chest as the angel went on. “But I— You know, I’m not… I hardly think we’ve been demoted, as it were. I remain in possession of my graces, and indeed, my Graces[2].”

“Very good, angel,” Crowley muttered, without enthusiasm. “Yeah, I haven’t noticed anything, but…”

“You don’t suppose they’ve…?”

“They can’t, can they?”

“I don’t see why not.”

“But that would stop us being…”

“I’m not so sure it would.”

“How’d you mean?”

There was a long, complicated pause on the other end of the line, and Crowley fancied he could see Aziraphale’s lips moving as he rehearsed what it was he wanted to say, tasting the words before he loaned them voice. Finally, he answered, “If he wants us to be as we are – that is to say, an angel and a demon – we are, we will be, an angel and a demon. But he… Well. I think the boy rather a similar flaw to mine, in that, ahem, he can’t really resist fixing something, if it might be fixed. And I was… I was thinking, dear boy, were I in such a position, what I might have done is just taken us off the books.”

Crowley understood. He wasn’t sure he liked that understanding, however, and so he repeated, “Taken us off the…?”

“Create a blindspot, as it were,” Aziraphale continued, without hearing him. “We are what we are. They are as they are. And never the twain shall meet.”

Crowley considered this for a long moment. The idea was unspeakable. To be as they were, but without their respective connections to Heaven and Hell, to be… Well. To be—

Unspeakable was right.

“Would you like to go for a drink?” Aziraphale asked, somewhat desperately.

“Oh, yes,” Crowley replied. “I’ll pick you up.”

–

They didn’t actually bother to go anywhere.

They sat down in the park, on the green, on a picnic blanket. It was a warm day, clinging onto the dregs of summer, and while they split a bottle of wine between them, none of the passing policemen on their beat much liked the idea of coming to break up their date. One of them was in a suit, and the other was in a thick wool jumper – suffice to stay, taking their Lafitte off them doesn’t seem like much cop when there were much more interesting bystanders to harass around London.

“What do we do?” Aziraphale asked.

“Dunno,” Crowley said. He took a sip of his wine, staring out over the duck pond. “Always thought about it. But I never really… I never really got as far as this point. I just thought, oh, wouldn’t it be nice…? And then thought about something else. Did you?”

“No,” Aziraphale said.

A beat passed. It spanned the silences of centuries.

“Yes,” he amended, guiltily, staring down at his knees, which were clad in sensible tan trousers. “But it was never going to happen. I— What is one to do?”

“Same stuff as always, I suppose,” Crowley said. “Just without reporting it to the men upstairs. Er, in your case, of course.”

“That’s not really cricket, is it?” Aziraphale asked.

Crowley, who did not believe the term “that’s not cricket” had been used by anyone else for at least a hundred years, said, “No.”

“I mean,” Aziraphale went on, “what would the point be? If we did it without reporting on it?”

“Human decency, I suppose,” Crowley said softly. Saying it didn’t avert the deep and crushing existential terror that was threatening to thunder down around his eyes, but it did meet a small bloom of satisfaction unfurl its flowers in his breast. He could be… He could be A.J. Crowley. He could just be… Anthony Crowley. No odd wishes, no giving up his powers, or his immortality. Just— Just being, and not having to report back downstairs.

His head spun.

“If it isn’t recorded, it hardly exists,” Aziraphale said, not really hearing Crowley. He was several leagues inside his own head, and he found the weather very unpleasant indeed. “Ergo, there’s no point doing it. And I’m… That is to say, one does rather need a point, to exist.”

“Why?” Crowley asked. “They don’t.” This was said with a vague gesture at the city around them. It was somewhat devoid of its usual, natural scorn. Then, he added, in a quietly hopeful tone, “And there’s the Arrangement[3].”

“But there’s no point to it,” Aziraphale snapped, “if there aren’t sides that we’re on. If we’re just— If we’re just you and me, dear boy, with the ties to our respective commands cut away, then the Arrangement becomes just that: you and me.”

“Yeah,” Crowley agreed, feeling himself grin. “Yeah, it does, doesn’t it?”

There was a long silence, and Crowley took a long sip of his drink, before glancing to his left, to see what had rendered Aziraphale silent. He followed Aziraphale’s downturned gaze, and his eyes alighted, through the dark lenses of his sunglasses, on his own hand. It was on top of Aziraphale’s, his fingers curled in to loosely clasp at it. The angel’s hand, Crowley noted, was quite warm, and his touch didn’t make Crowley’s body any more inclined to burst into flames, or to smoke, or do anything along those lines, than it usually was.

“Ah,” Aziraphale said. “Are you… Are you sure, my dear?”

“Nope,” Crowley said, with a grin. “I’m not sure of anything.” He squeezed. After another moment’s pause, Aziraphale’s hand shifted in his own, their fingers interlinking, and he heard Aziraphale exhale breathily. “D’you want to go to dinner?”

“Sushi?” Aziraphale asked, hopefully. He had scooted slightly closer, so that their shoulders were touching. If Crowley was a human, his cheeks would have flushed. He wasn’t one, but… What the Hell? He blushed anyway.

“Why not? Let’s… Let’s order just starters. Eat from the same plates.”

“We usually eat from the same plates,” Aziraphale said. By this, he meant, “I usually eat from your plate,” as Crowley did not have the same appetite Aziraphale did, and often left his food unfinished.

“Yes,” Crowley agreed. “Yes. But— But let’s make a spectacle of it.”

“We don’t know,” Aziraphale began.

“Yes, we do,” Crowley decided, and this was how he showed he’d decided: he leaned closer, so that his head rested on Aziraphale’s shoulder, still holding his hand. He could feel the heat of his flush burning his cheeks, and he could feel his body’s heart pumping a good deal more vigorously than usual. It was rather nice. “Yes,” he decided a second time, for good measure. “We do.”

“Oh,” Aziraphale said, breathlessly. “Yes, I… I suppose we do.”

For a long, long few minutes, they sat there, drinking their wine. Crowley leaned his head against Aziraphale’s shoulder, and Aziraphale put his cheek in toward the top of it, enjoying the spiced scent of the product Crowley wore to soften his hair.  The sun began to set over Soho.

“Crowley?” Aziraphale asked.

“Hm?”

“Let’s split a dessert.” It was said with such reckless enthusiasm that Crowley heard himself laugh. Later on, Aziraphale would eat the whole thing, bar for a mouthful, because Crowley wasn’t actually one for dessert, but the point would be the look of the thing, the spectacle, and they would order it together.

“Alright,” he agreed, readily. He raised his wine glass. “To our godson, then. He did very well without our influence, didn’t he?”

“Yes,” Aziraphale said, raising his own glass, and letting it clink against Crowley’s. “We should… We should visit him.”

“Would be nice to do,” Crowley mused. “What with us being— Being retired, and all.”

“Yes,” Aziraphale agreed. They drained their glasses. “Retired!”

“We could buy a cottage in Tadfield, and go there on weekends,” Crowley said impulsively. “Dunroamin.”

“Dunmiracling.”

“Dundemoning.”

“Dunangeling.”

“Dun.”

“Dun!”

They sat together in the silence, and as one, they fell back on the grass, staring up at the reddening skies, and feeling the warmth of each other’s palms, pressed tight together. In the stars, Crowley could divine no purpose at all.

It was unspeakable.

It was wonderful.

[1] In fact, Crowley did, but he hadn’t looked at it. He hadn’t needed to.

[2] One might mistakenly believe that one cannot capitalize words in spoken conversation, but Aziraphale rather had the knack.

[3] Crowley, too, was able to capitalise words with his voice alone, although he ordinarily needed to have heard Aziraphale performing the practice first. Luckily, he usually had.

body:
They went to the Ritz again, where a table was mysteriously vacant. And perhaps the recent exertions had had some fallout in the nature of reality because, while they were eating, for the first time ever, a nightingale sang in Berkeley Square.

~ Good Omens by Terry Pratchett & Neil Gaiman

title: The Loopholes in Ineffability - Ash_and_Ember - Good Omens - Neil Gaiman & Terry Pratchett [Archive of Our Own]
excerpt: An Archive of Our Own, a project of the Organization for Transformative Works
description: The Arrangement is such a big part of Aziraphale and Crowley’s relationship, yet it’s never shown how it actually happened. This is my short, unedited, imagining of how it went down 1000 years ago

summary: So every time I reread good omens I notice new stuff for the first time but I can’t believe I didn’t notice this until my 10th...
body:
So every time I reread good omens I notice new stuff for the first time

but I can’t believe I didn’t notice this until my 10th reread:

And this isn’t even from the perspective of any of the characters it’s literally t h e n a r r a t i o n
